The answer is that the first line of a new system is always the most expensive. Because you have to develop all the underlying engineering and navigation systems etc.  Future expansion of the metrolink will be less expensive

@PaulSpCork This project will be delivered by Transport Infrastructure Ireland who are experts at delivering transport infrastructure, their last project, Luas Cross City was on time and on budget. In fact it was delivered slightly ahead of schedule.  I believe we can reach the lower figure

@GalHibernia Yes, there's increases planned for every county in the country.  You can see what improvements are planned here: https://t.co/zPw5XDKCVL
@Liam220262 BusConnects is delivering a better bus system.

@Liam220262 That was for Metro North, Metrolink is a different project announced in 2018 that serves different areas and operates to a different level of modernity.  It would be great if it could be built a week from now, but a megaproject like the metro takes time

@GalHibernia There are dozens of new routes and improvements to be introduced across Ireland later this year as part of the Connecting Ireland programme.  Routes will be continually added and improved over several years.  For example Carlow will receive a dedicated town bus service in Q4

@CharlesBracken Hi Charles, there is bus priority as part of BusConnects for the Docklands and a from Bus√°ras to Heuston as part of the Liffey Cycle Route.  These are large engineering schemes so will take several years to complete.  For interim measures you might contact Dublin City Council

@Liam220262 Yes, we're designing a Metro, we're designing rail system upgrades, we're designing new Luas lines and extensions. Two BusConnects Corridors have been submitted to ABP and we've increased walking and cycling infrastructure funding to its highest level ever.

Whilst the process is not immediate, new bus routes and all night trams take planning, and importantly need people to run them.  Remember that even if a new 24 hour route doesn't run to your area, people who take those buses aren't using taxis so there's more available for all.

With plans to introduce more 24 hour bus routes and increases to frequency on existing 24 hour routes, @TFIupdates are taking steps to enable more night time journeys in Dublin to be made using public transport.  The NTA are also examining how the @luas can operate past 1am https://t.co/4M3DWeMjsM
